p: Annual excess mortality appears to have increased over recent decades, perhaps because the number of elderly and immunocompromised individuals has also increased [ 3], and is typically higher in A(H3N2) infections than in A(H1N1)pdm09 infections [ 5]. Infection due to influenza B viruses is often perceived to be milder than influenza A virus infection [ 6]. However, similar clinical features between outpatients infected with seasonal influenza A or B viruses and no clinical differences between influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 and A(H3N2) in the post-pandemic period have been reported [ 7â€“ 9]. In hospitalized patients, some independent factors have been associated with mortality and intensive care unit (ICU) admission [ 10, 11], but studies of the factors associated with severity according to the influenza type or subtype are scarce [ 12]. Given the year-to-year variability in influenza severity, research on factors associated with poor outcomes for the different types and subtypes is needed to prepare ICU capacity and health resources [ 13, 14].
